entry.summary: What & Why Privacy coins are cryptocurrencies that preserve anonymity by obscuring the flow of money across their networks. With the recent crack-down on Tornado Cash, and imposed blacklists on stablecoins (Circle’s USDC), privacy coins are becoming more and more relevant. We want to explore…
entry.content:
What & Why

Privacy coins are cryptocurrencies that preserve anonymity by obscuring the flow of money across their networks. With the recent crack-down on Tornado Cash, and imposed blacklists on stablecoins (Circle’s USDC), privacy coins are becoming more and more relevant. We want to explore popular privacy coins and estimate opportunities & market size for privacy-based payments.

Questions

  • What is the current market cap of privacy coins?
  • Is it possible that privacy coins will grow in demand more than crypto in general?
  • How will CBDCs and government regulation on KYC affect privacy coins?
  • What are the most promising privacy coins?
  • How many transactions on-chain are private?

Data

  • Monero & Zcash Interest 
  • Privacy Token & Privacy Coin Interest 
  • Monero & Zcash Transactions 
  • Bitcoin/Ethereum vs. Privacy Coin Transactions 
  • Monero Transaction Count 
  • Percentage of Criminal Activity in Crypto 

Findings

  • Monero, Zcash, Decred, Oasis Network, Horizen, Secret, Keep Network, Phala Network, Verge, Dusk Network, PIVX, Navcoin are the most popular privacy coins
  • Ring signatures, stealth addresses, identity masking, zero-knowledge proofs, tx-amount obfuscation are the most common technologies used by privacy coins
  • Privacy coins are used less for illegal activity as assumed, and more to protect personal privacy for legal payments, cross-border payments, donations, etc.
  • Only 0.15% of all crypto transactions are related to illegal activity
  • Privacy coin transactions make up only 1-2% of all crypto transactions

Risks

  • Regulation will be too tight on privacy coins, making them effectively useless (with its only use case being criminal activity)
  • Privacy might not be valued enough by most users, especially when compared to transaction speed or access to handouts/benefits as would be the case with CBDCs

Predictions

  • Privacy coins are unlikely to work with smart contracts due to their anonymous nature, and as such, will likely focus on payments exclusively
  • Privacy coins are already banned in KR, AU, JP, and more countries will likely ban them at the risk of illegal activity
  • If regulations crack down on payment privacy, a parallel “gray” economy might emerge (and not for illegal activity, but rather just to preserve privacy)
  • Implementation of CBDCs will cause a discussion around privacy, with the main argument in favor being the “greater good” and “public security” - this might become a trigger for a subset of users deciding to switch to privacy-protecting coins
  • As with most technologies, early adopters are using the tech for shady activity, but with time mainstream users will adopt privacy tokens for day-to-day transfers

Opportunities

  • Betting on the price increase of privacy coins, relative to Bitcoin (especially as CBDC implementations are getting closer)
  • Currently, privacy coins have a bad reputation of being used mostly for illegal activity, which might change rapidly once regular users start using them more and more

entry.title: Topic #4 - Non Fungible Tokens
entry.summary: What & Why Non-fungible tokens are digital asset representations, most commonly used for digital art (images, videos). NFTs have seen an immense increase in demand during the 2021/2022 bull run. We are investigating whether this trend was short-lived, whether NFTs are here to stay long-term,…
entry.content:
What & Why

Non-fungible tokens are digital asset representations, most commonly used for digital art (images, videos). NFTs have seen an immense increase in demand during the 2021/2022 bull run. We are investigating whether this trend was short-lived, whether NFTs are here to stay long-term, and what NFT use cases could look like in the future.

Questions

  • What are the most common NFT use cases right now?
  • What could be the most common NFT use cases in the future?
  • Were NFTs just a short-lived fad, or is there more behind them?
  • What is the potential market for digital art?
  • What is the current market of physical art?
  • What are optimistic/pessimistic cases for NFT adoption?

Data

  • OpenSea Monthly ETH Volume 
  • OpenSea Monthly NFTs Sold 
  • OpenSea Monthly Active Traders 
  • OpenSea Monthly Volume Polygon 
  • Art Market Sales Worldwide 

Findings

  • Depending on NFT regulation (whether NFTs are classified as security or utility) the market might see more/less growth
  • The global art market value is approx. 65 billion USD per year, and it is reasonable to assume the digital art market could capture 10-20% of that (similar to how Bitcoin grew to approx. 10% of Golds market value)
  • Most NFT projects come and go quickly, with only 2 out of the top 10 projects being more than a year old (Cryptopunks and Bored Apes)
  • Liquidity seems to be the most significant problem for NFTs, with demand having dried up rapidly after the initial hype
  • NFTs with utility are becoming more popular, such as NFTs granting unique benefits to holders
  • Only approx. 10% are buying NFTs for art (long-term), 90% are buying to make a profit or to flex to the community (short-term)

Predictions

  • Fractional NFTs will dominate in the future due to better liquidity and easier access to own a piece of a whole
  • Physical assets will see more digitization through NFTs, especially with fractional NFTs enabling users to hold parts of physical assets such as land and real estate
  • NFTs use cases for music, ticketing, gift cards, access passes, game items/skins will increase, while the use-case for digital art will likely grow at a slower pace
  • NFTs will have to present unique utility value, brand value (such as Nike Sneaker NFTs) or physical value (fractional real estate, etc.) to gain demand
  • The days of unknown artists releasing a collection of 10000 similar looking collectibles purely on hype are over
  • Demand for NFT collections will be highly skewed towards top projects, even more as with fungible tokens, with top 0.1-1% receiving 90-99% of all trading activity (primarily due to the lack of liquidity)
  • Gaming will offer the best use-case for NFTs, with tradable in-game items, skins and avatars on the blockchain
  • The high-end/luxury market will see an increase in NFT demand, especially when combined with brand value and perceived uniqueness
  • Bitcoin could become the most dominant way to issue NFTs (via the Taro protocol on the Lightning Network)
  • While many 2017 alt-tokens saw their demand increase once again during the 2021 bull market, most NFT projects released in 2021/2022 will likely die (due to lack of fractional liquidity)
  • It is unlikely that NFTs will receive as much hype as they did in 2021 ever again - we expect that NFT demand will slowly recover to all-time-highs, although over many years and with drastically different use-cases (mostly powered by gaming and virtual economy)
  • NFTs will be based on the actual value they represent (such as ticket value, digital fractions of physical assets, in-game item/skin, access/governance passes), as opposed to speculative art value except in a few rare cases

entry.title: Topic #3 - Central Bank Digital Currencies
entry.summary: What & Why Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) have been in discussion recently by the Federal Reserve and ECB, with China, Russia, and India having already launched some form of CBDC. CBDCs are digital payment systems, with users owning accounts directly with the central bank…
entry.content:
What & Why

Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) have been in discussion recently by the Federal Reserve and ECB, with China, Russia, and India having already launched some form of CBDC.

CBDCs are digital payment systems, with users owning accounts directly with the central bank (instead of intermediary banks). Central banks have exclusive control over the digital currency, which raises questions about potential abuse of power and dangers such as Orwellian control, surveillance, and censorship.

Questions

  • What are the advantages/disadvantages of CBDCs compared to Bitcoin?
  • What are the advantages/disadvantages of CBDCs compared to the current way banks work?
  • How dangerous are CBDCs regarding freedom, free speech & censorship?
  • How likely will central banks introduce negative interest rates to promote spending?
  • How likely will central banks start to promote social credit type of schemes?
  • Is there a danger in central banks using the collected payment data against users?
  • Can inflation control and GDP growth be controlled better with CBDCs?
  • What is the tradeoff between the efficiency of digital money vs. censorship and control?

Data

  • CBDC search interest 

Optimistic Predictions

  • CBDCs will offer better safety for the majority of the population due to the simple way to track and intervene
  • Since CBDCs are provided by a single institution, it will be easy to interlink CBDCs with each other, offering efficient and cheap cross-border payment solutions
  • People will not see any difference between credit cards and CBDCs (possibly even benefits in payment speed and cost)
  • People will likely receive “free money” to switch from existing systems (the switch will happen at the perceived free will of people)
  • CBDCs are the dream for socialist-driven politics, and naturally, a large part of society will openly and enthusiastically welcome CBDCs with their potential benefits for the “greater good”
  • CBDCs provide an excellent narrative for owning gold and crypto (and will likely trigger the largest bull run for these hard assets that provide privacy and ownership control)
  • Prevents counterfeiting, avoidance of crime/tax evasion, more financial inclusion
  • Direct cash injections benefitting (in the short-term) individual races, groups, or well-behaving people according to policies that central authorities want to encourage
  • Negative interest rates to encourage spending and increase the velocity of money
  • Programmable money, open APIs for 3rd party developers, easier (although automatic) taxation through automatic deductions from accounts
  • Tax authorities can drastically reduce their staff and operational expenses since taxes can be easily calculated and deducted automatically (same applies for credited tax refunds)
  • A massive demand for privacy/payment-oriented cryptocurrencies that are truly trustless & decentralized (people will vote with their behavior and eventually replace centralized CBDCs due to declining purchasing power and impractical policies/regulations)
  • The free market/open source developers will be more agile and reactive to real-time demands by users (e-CNY is inferior to WeChat pay and Alipay), causing users to prefer cryptos over CBDCs out of convenience
  • Getting users to change from credit cards/cryptos to CBDCs (including installing apps, identification software, etc.) will require immense upfront incentives such as money handouts (or an orchestrated panic, either via a cyber attack on financial systems or massive market crash)
  • It is unlikely CBDCs will gain broad acceptance due to inconvenience unless the public is forced to use them (it will be a battle between forced agenda and human nature)

Pessimistic Predictions

  • A social credit system is the logical next step after having complete control over people’s spending data
  • CO2/energy credits and similar consumption credits can be easily enforced and likely will be enforced
  • A total ban on cash and cryptos, making CBDC use mandatory through regulation (if people are given the option to decide, CBDCs will unlikely gain acceptance as seen with eCNY)
  • All intermediary banks will go bankrupt through an orchestrated financial crash, and unlike in 2008 these banks won’t be rescued
  • CBDCs encourage central planning, with governments likely overstepping into socialist/full control measures (it is almost impossible for free markets to flourish with authoritarian control by one party over the payment layer)
  • With the obvious incompetence by central banks, it is almost guaranteed that CBDCs will turn out horribly for people (with all the expected dangers like censorship, frozen accounts, and social credit systems)
  • CBDCs will cause sanctions against individuals, companies, and nations, who don’t comply with the policies of central authorities
  • Control over payments, connected to the rise of artificial intelligence (facial recognition, etc.) poses a threat to freedom, with some form of social credit system being only a matter of time
  • The balance sheets of central banks are technically infinite and don’t need to be balanced with assets; hence central banks can create money even easier than before and hand it out based on policies/narratives instead of real economic value
  • Progressive taxation based on usage (gas/energy, meat consumption, etc.)
  • Gives the central bank complete control over means of production, using artificial intelligence to evaluate the collected payment data (a socialists dream) - USSR top-down centrally planned market failed because decisions were based on delayed estimates & incomplete information - CBDC real-time evaluation of payment data could cause a centrally planned economy that actually appears to work
  • No competition between banks to offer better terms, service, interest rates, etc.
  • Automatic deductions of penalties from accounts, whether in the form of one-time deduction (speeding ticket) or varying debit based on some formula (CO2 credits, etc.)
  • CBDCs will be introduced to the market by providing extensive handouts and significant incentives (to get people to change the status quo)
  • Long-term effects of CBDC handouts will likely cause massive inflation and inefficiencies (that interventionists will try to resolve through more policies & regulations)
  • Transition to CBDCs will be met with a lot of resistance (especially in the West), but will eventually be forced upon people through strictly outlawing cash (rhetoric will change as it did with the requirement of vaccines, from voluntary and recommended to mandatory for the greater good fighting yet another invisible enemy)
  • The next logical step after CBDCs (or parallel to it) is the introduction of an identification system for users (accessible as API for 3rd parties) - this comes with additional dangers in regards to privacy, access control, and censorship
  • CBDCs will likely become transitory currencies that people will try to exchange for hard assets (like in AR/CU/VE)
  • As long as the government & central banks are honest, CBDCs seem like an advantage, however, if governments start abusing the additional power for their own interest, the downsides massively outweigh the upsides of a CBDC
  • Stimulus checks/UBI will become the norm for income while the workforce is slowly replaced by AI & redundant labor
  • CBDCs are more restrictive and provide less utility than cryptos, making them the unpopular choice compared to cryptos and other digital payment methods
  • The central bank will be the sole trusted authority and prone to internal/external cyber attacks and other “single points of failure” that could be largely avoided in a decentralized/trustless system
  • Central banks are intentionally discrediting the innovation around cryptocurrencies (decentralization, openness, privacy) to maintain control and power
  • Cryptocurrencies (especially payment & privacy-oriented ones) will be regulated out of existence (or made inaccessible by most people), since they compete directly with CBDCs

Opportunities

  • Long payment cryptocurrencies for crypto adoption (Bitcoin with its lightning network)
  • Long privacy cryptocurrencies for privacy narrative (Monero, Zcash, Verge, Navcoin)
  • Short banks/payment companies for replacement narrative (JPM, BAC, WFC, PYPL)
  • Exit the traditional banking system (gold, self-sufficiency, geographical diversification)

Links

  • Atlantic Council CBDC tracker https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/cbdctracker/ 
  • An opportunity for the monetary system https://www.bis.org/publ/arpdf/ar2021e3.htm
  • Chinas digital currency https://www.csis.org/blogs/new-perspectives-asia/chinas-progress-towards-central-bank-digital-currency 
  • What Chinese digital currency is not https://digichina.stanford.edu/work/lets-start-with-what-chinas-digital-currency-is-not/ 
  • Chinese digital currency and blockchain network https://digichina.stanford.edu/work/chinas-digital-currency-and-blockchain-network-disparate-projects-or-two-sides-of-the-same-coin/

entry.title: Topic #2 - Population Growth
entry.summary: What & Why The population is estimated to grow for the next 100 years (up to 10.4B, as projected by the UN), before beginning to decline. We want to look at different population growth projections, estimate its effects, and understand differences in growth between regions.
entry.content:
What & Why

The population is estimated to grow for the next 100 years (up to 10.4B, as projected by the UN), before beginning to decline. We want to look at different population growth projections, estimate its effects, and understand differences in growth between regions.

Questions

  • What regions will have the fastest population growth?
  • What regions will have the fastest population decline?
  • What are the implications of population growth?
  • Can world resources sustain a doubling in population?
  • What are the possibilities of black swan events affecting population growth?
  • What are the population growth differences between races?
  • How is belief and religion linked to population growth?
  • How is the wealth of a nation linked to population growth?
  • What would the world look like in terms of population in 50 and 100 years?

Data

  • UN population projections 

  • Fertility rate

  • Population projections by country 
  • Global population younger than 15 
  • Population growth rate 
  • Population projections 
  • World population by region 
  • Children per woman vs. GDP 
  • Children per woman vs. HDI 
  • World population by region 

Findings

  • Education is the most significant factor for the decrease in fertility rates
  • Lower child mortality, access to birth control & family planning are highly correlated with lower growth in population
  • The world (by resources) will have no problem sustaining 10B people 

Predictions

  • Rapidly declining fertility rate due to education & access to birth control & abortion
  • A young population of a nation indicates long-term economic health
  • Africa & Asia will become the strongest economies simply due to their large young population (8 of 10 people will live in Africa or Asia by 2100)
  • Social media will drastically affect how people perceive having family
  • Europe will become the oldest region by age, with unclear viability around financing all the elderly people
  • Stronger campaigns to prevent population growth from getting too high (education, family planning, vaccines, social media indoctrination)
  • China has reached its peak population, and will decline from here onwards, resulting in IN surpassing CN in terms of economy
  • There will be a new voluntary growth spurt in highly educated and developed regions
  • A black swan event (biological/chemical attack, nuclear war) can not be excluded and might drastically alter projections
  • Massive opportunity growth in Africa & South Asia, massive opportunity/economic decline in Europe

  • World population growth https://ourworldindata.org/world-population-growth

  • Age structure https://ourworldindata.org/age-structure

entry.title: Topic #1 - Cryptocurrencies
entry.summary: What & Why Cryptocurrencies have been trending in 2017 and in 2021 due to their opportunity to revolutionize traditional finance. Most notably, Bitcoin grew in popularity, gaining over 10000% to up to $69,000 per coin, raising the question of whether it can successfully lead the…
entry.content:
What & Why

Cryptocurrencies have been trending in 2017 and in 2021 due to their opportunity to revolutionize traditional finance. Most notably, Bitcoin grew in popularity, gaining over 10000% to up to $69,000 per coin, raising the question of whether it can successfully lead the future of finance and serve as a digital alternative to Gold.

Questions

  • Could crypto replace traditional finance?
  • Can Bitcoin survive in the long term?
  • Can Bitcoin grow to more than 10% of Gold’s market capitalization?
  • Can crypto survive regulatory pressure?
  • What would the world look like with everyone using crypto?
  • What drove the previous bull runs? What might cause the next ones?
  • Does Bitcoin serve as a good inflation hedge?
  • What is the risk of black swan events?

Data

  • Crypto Trends

  • Unique BTC addresses 
  • Exchange BTC traded volume 
  • Confirmed BTC transactions 
  • Active ETH addresses 
  • Daily ETH transactions 

Risks

  • Satoshi selling their stake of 1 million Bitcoins
  • Bitcoin being exposed as US government experiment, making RU/CN more suspicious of it
  • Extremely harsh regulations (consumer protection, environment, securities laws)
  • Competition with government-issued digital currencies
  • Tighter controls around Internet access
  • Quantum computing cracking SHA256
  • Network attacks and mining centralization
  • Anti-Proof of Work regulations
  • Harsh securities laws applied to most crypto tokens
  • Statistically likely that underlying tech fails or becomes exploited
  • Not enough demand for “digital gold”
  • Not enough performance to compete with centralized payment systems (CBDC)
  • No narratives to drive subsequent bull runs

Optimistic Predictions

  • Crypto & DeFi operate alongside central bank currencies successfully
  • CBDCs handle the payment layer, while DeFi/crypto handles all layer-2 applications
  • Bitcoin is successfully maintained, despite all security risks, enabling it to survive for the foreseeable future
  • Bitcoin gains acceptance as digital Gold and adoption grows for individuals, companies, governments
  • Bitcoin is just at the beginning of an S-curve adoption, with early adopters using the technology exclusively so far (we will see a massive adoption over the next 20-30 years)
  • Adoption will be driven by India, Asia, Latin America, and Africa, where most users just come online and have yet to discover the power of frictionless payments
  • Bitcoin will become easy-to-use, extremely fast with cheap fees through a layer-2 solution like the lightning network
  • Bitcoin will be denominated in sats, increasing the perception of owning “cheaper” Bitcoin
  • Crypto will build upon its strong values (trustlessness, anti-censorship, decentralization), out-competing CBDCs, which are trying to regulate, control, and censor their users

Pessimistic Predictions

  • Crypto struggles to gain adoption as central bank digital currencies push it out of the market
  • Crypto will become too regulated in regards to privacy, access (only professional investors), environmental laws, securities laws
  • A black-swan event (see risks) destroys all confidence in the early cryptocurrencies
  • End-users don’t care about decentralization
  • Original cryptos (Bitcoin etc.) persist in their use as storage of value while losing their use as a payment layer
  • Original cryptos (Bitcoin etc.) persist in their use as a payment layer while losing their use as storage of value
  • Bitcoin will not reach an S-curve adoption as expected (as compared to Internet or mobile phone adoption) due to a lack of use-case

  • Etherscan stats
  • Bitcoin user adoption report

entry.title: The "OG Token" Hypothesis
entry.summary: In each crypto cycle, new narratives begin to drive and lead the bull market. In 2017, ICOs, mining, masternodes, Chinese market tokens (NEO, Qtum, Vechain), unique L1s (DAGs such as Iota/Raiblocks), and Bitcoin as “digital gold” were the main narratives for the bull market. The…
entry.content:
In each crypto cycle, new narratives begin to drive and lead the bull market. In 2017, ICOs, mining, masternodes, Chinese market tokens (NEO, Qtum, Vechain), unique L1s (DAGs such as Iota/Raiblocks), and Bitcoin as “digital gold” were the main narratives for the bull market.

The 2021/2022 cycle began with DeFi and quickly turned into an incredible run for NFTs, metaverse, lending, staking, and yield farming narratives. Most notably, the 2021/2022 bull run was driven by meme tokens (promotion of Dogecoin by Elon) and the emergence of Binance Smart Chain (Safemoon), letting anyone launch tokens based on hype (shilled to financially uneducated Gen-Z on TikTok and Instagram).

This leads us to the question of whether we can predict the narrative that will drive the next bull market or even grow uncorrelated to Bitcoin. From all our bets, we want to share one big hypothesis for the coming bull market, betting on potentially upcoming regulations: stronger asset security laws, ESG, environment, cannabis, and payments with strong usability (CBDC alternatives).

In both the 2017 bull market and the 2021/2022 bull market, many people lost money by investing in ICOs/tokens that are nothing but unregistered securities. These tokens will likely be regulated out of the market or sold to zero by continuous sell pressure from founders/early investors.

We believe that coins definitively passing the Howey test will be considered valuable (again), especially tokens that have passed the test of time with an organic distribution (=no presale). We call this the OG Token Hypothesis.

What are these particular OG tokens? Tokens that were launched 8-10 years ago without a presale and distributed via mining or staking. Candidates include Dogecoin, Namecoin, Peercoin, Feathercoin, Vertcoin, Reddcoin, Nxt, Navcoin, Blackcoin, Hempcoin, Potcoin, and similar. These have a rich history, some even very active development, and mature communities.

Why OG Tokens?

Let’s look at some arguments which might contribute to possible narratives around these “OG tokens.”

- Blockchains operating since 2012/2013 - some of the oldest blockchains after Bitcoin
- Owning part of crypto history as a fungible token (with better liquidity than NFTs)
- Unlikely classified as security! (Any security regulation will be favorable for these tokens)
- Were top 10 once (brand value), crypto OGs know Peercoin, Namecoin, Feathercoin, etc.
- Peercoin as the first-proof-of-stake coin, Namecoin as the first blockchain focused on identity & asset registry.
- Peercoin & Namecoin at ~15m market cap, Navcoin at ~3m market cap, - Feathercoin at ~2m market cap (compared to Litecoin, Dogecoin at a multi-billion dollar market cap)
- Passing the test of time with 8-10 years of history
- Active development (Peercoin, Vertcoin, Blackcoin, Navcoin)
- Potential listings on large exchanges if interest grows again
- Potential narratives around first-proof-of-stake, ESG, and environment/green tokens (Peercoin) - especially if Washington and - - Brussels decide to penalize PoW mining
- Potential narratives around cannabis legalization (Hempcoin, Potcoin)- Hash-rate is slowly growing (with a recent boost by ETH switching to PoS)
- Potential narratives around privacy-oriented blockchains (Navcoin)
- Largely governed by the community (with oversight by foundations, for example the Peercoin Foundation, which publishes yearly financial reports
- Highly distributed Peercoin has 53,639 addresses, Namecoin has 52,146 addresses, Navcoin has 25,065 addresses, Blackcoin 19,336 addresses, Feathercoin has 12,579 addresses

Risks and Concerns

Our biggest concern is the lack of liquidity for these tokens (which will also cause a massive supply shortage in case the proposed narrative starts gaining traction). Many of these tokens are listed only on Bittrex or exchanges that are old and not used by recent crypto entrants. Larger exchanges don’t want to deal with the maintenance of small market cap blockchains. This isn’t likely to change unless the market demands it, as was the case with Dogecoin.

Prices

Let us create a paper portfolio of some low market cap picks and track them over a few years relative to BTC. We believe the risk/reward is incredibly high, likely above 10:1 for a multi-year holding period. We also acknowledge that some of our picks (statistically, as history shows) might experience hacks or dump to zero over a long enough horizon. Regardless, we think the tokens that make it will compensate for the losses.

Sample portfolio, with prices as of Oct 6th 2022. 
Peercoin - $0.55
Namecoin - $1.10
Navcoin - $0.046
Feathercoin - $0.0077
Blackcoin - $0.015
Hempcoin - $0.0027
Potcoin - $0.0032
